part.partText: opposite, spreading, stalkless, yellow-green, egg-shaped (2 - 5 cm wide, 5 - 15 cm long) with long pointy tips, wide bases, and smooth margins.
(1 - 20) stalkless, yellow-white or green-white, almost closed, and compactly clustered at the top of the stem.
five, connected below, with separate tips having smooth edges and a ridge-like structure (keel) running down the outer face to the connected tube portion.
five but fused with shorter membranes (plaits) between the actual petals.
a two-valved, elliptic capsule with numerous flattened, winged, smooth seeds.

similarSpecies.comments: This is the only whitish-flowered gentian in our area except for the rare albino of other species. Albino forms of Gentiana andrewsii or its varieties have rough-prickly leaf margins, hairy margined sepal tips, and plaits longer than the alternating petals. Albino forms of G. puberulenta may also be similar, but they have a hairy stem, very narrow sepal tips, opened flowers, and separate anthers.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Moist prairies, sometimes swales or other wet or moist clearings, but uncommon overall.

etymology.comments: Gentiana is named after Gentius, king of Illyria, who supposedly discovered a medicinal value for the yellow gentian. Alba is the Latin word for white, which refers to the whitish flowers.
